steps.text: Recognize anaphylaxis: Symptoms include throat tightening, difficulty breathing, swelling of face/lips/tongue, hives, dizziness, rapid pulse. Can progress within minutes
Call 911 immediately: State 'severe allergic reaction' or 'anaphylaxis.' This is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate medical care
Locate epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen): Check person's bag, pockets, or ask them. Many allergy sufferers carry one. Time is critical
Use EpiPen: Remove safety cap. Hold orange tip against outer mid-thigh (through clothing is OK). Press firmly until click. Hold for 10 seconds
Position the person: If conscious and breathing, have them sit up for easier breathing. If showing signs of shock (pale, dizzy), lay flat with legs elevated
Monitor breathing: Watch chest rise and fall. If breathing stops, begin CPR immediately. Be prepared - condition can deteriorate rapidly
Second dose: If symptoms don't improve or return after 5-15 minutes, give second EpiPen on opposite thigh if available
Stay until EMS arrives: Even if symptoms improve, person must go to hospital. Biphasic reaction can occur hours later
Remove or stop exposure to allergen
Give antihistamine if available and person can swallow
Watch for signs of worsening: difficulty breathing, swelling
Apply cool compress to itchy areas
Call 911 if symptoms worsen rapidly
Seek medical attention if reaction is severe or persistent

name: Bee Sting
description: Insect sting with potential allergic reaction

steps.text: Remove stinger by scraping sideways with credit card
Clean area with soap and water
Apply ice to reduce swelling
Take antihistamine for itching
Watch for signs of allergic reaction
Call 911 if difficulty breathing or widespread reaction
